test_name: RBI Grade B Phase 1 - Mock Test #7

questions.question: What was India's Current Account Deficit (CAD) as a percentage of GDP in the second quarter of the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: India’s current account deficit (CAD) moderated to 1.2 per cent of GDP in Q2:2024-25, down from 1.3 per cent of GDP in the corresponding quarter of the previous year. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the unemployment rate for individuals aged 15 years and above in 2023-24, as per the annual Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) report?
questions.explanation: As per the 2023-24 annual PLFS report, the unemployment rate for individuals aged 15 years and above has steadily declined from 6 per cent in 2017-18 to 3.2 per cent in 2023-24. (Page 76, Para 1.65)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In its February 2025 monetary policy meeting, by how many basis points did the Reserve Bank of India increase the repo rate to combat inflation?
questions.explanation: To manage rising inflation, the RBI's Monetary Policy Committee increased the repo rate by 25 basis points in February 2025, taking it from 6.50% to 6.75%.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In June 2024, the RBI revised the definition of 'bulk deposits' for scheduled commercial banks (excluding RRBs) and small finance banks. What is the new threshold for a single rupee term deposit to be classified as a bulk deposit?
questions.explanation: On a review, the definition of bulk deposits was revised to ‘Single Rupee Term Deposits of ₹3 Crore and Above’ for SCBs (excluding RRBs) and SFBs, up from the previous limit of ₹2 crore. (Page 283)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Return on Equity (RoE) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) remained strong, reaching a near decadal high in March 2024. What was this reported figure?
questions.explanation: In March 2024, the Return on Equity (RoE) for the banking sector was 13.8 per cent, bolstered by high net interest margins and strong credit demand. (Page 18, 58)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's estimated GDP growth for the second quarter (Q2) of the fiscal year 2024-25, as reported in November 2024?
questions.explanation: As per the data released in November 2024, India's GDP growth for Q2 of the fiscal year 2024-25 was estimated at 7.2%.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Core inflation, which is CPI excluding food and fuel, fell to what level in February 2024, marking one of the lowest prints in the current CPI series?
questions.explanation: In February 2024, core inflation (i.e., CPI excluding food and fuel) fell to 3.4 per cent, among the lowest prints in the current CPI series (2012=100). (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the substitution of Section 148, what is the maximum period within which an assessee is required to furnish a return of income after a notice for escaped assessment is issued?

options.A: 30 days from the end of the month of notice
options.B: 60 days from the end of the month of notice
options.C: 90 days from the end of the month of notice
options.D: Three months from the end of the month of notice
options.E: Six months from the end of the month of notice

questions.explanation: The substituted section 148(1) requires the assessee to furnish a return within such period as specified in the notice, which shall not exceed three months from the end of the month in which the notice is issued. (Page 54)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the recommendations of the 56th GST Council meeting in September 2025, what is the revised GST rate on Cement?
questions.explanation: The 56th GST Council meeting approved a major rate rationalisation, which included the reduction of GST on Cement from 28% to 18%.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The report notes a 'paradoxical' situation where banks simultaneously placed substantial funds under the Standing Deposit Facility (SDF) while borrowing heavily from the Marginal Standing Facility (MSF). What key measure was introduced by the RBI effective December 30, 2023, to address this and improve fund management?

options.A: The spread between MSF and SDF rates was increased.
options.B: A penal charge was introduced for using both facilities on the same day.
options.C: Reversal of liquidity facilities under both SDF and MSF was permitted even on weekends and holidays.
options.D: The borrowing limit under MSF was reduced for banks using the SDF facility.
options.E: Banks were mandated to choose only one of the two facilities on any given day.

questions.explanation: To address the paradoxical situation of simultaneous high usage of both SDF and MSF and to enable better fund management, the RBI decided to allow the reversal of liquidity facilities under both SDF and MSF even during weekends and holidays, effective from December 30, 2023. (Page 113, Para III.22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new section 44BBC has been inserted for computing profits for non-residents engaged in the business of operating cruise ships. What percentage of the aggregate amounts received is deemed to be profits and gains of such business?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted section 44BBC(1) states that for a non-resident assessee in the business of operating cruise ships, a sum equal to twenty per cent of the aggregate amounts specified in sub-section (2) shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of such business. (Page 41, 170)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the revised SAARC Currency Swap Framework for 2024-27, what is the total corpus for the newly introduced INR swap window?
questions.explanation: Under the new SAARC currency swap framework 2024-27, an Indian Rupee (INR) swap window has been introduced with various concessions for swap support in INR with a total corpus of ₹250 billion. (Page 210, Box X.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the credit risk sensitivity analysis, what magnitude of shock in terms of standard deviations (SD) to the GNPA ratio would be required to bring the system-level CRAR below the regulatory minimum of 9 per cent?
questions.explanation: The reverse stress test within the credit risk sensitivity analysis shows that a shock of 5.1 standard deviations would be required to bring the system-level Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) below the regulatory minimum of 9 per cent. (Page 87)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average spread of the Weighted Average Call Rate (WACR) over the policy repo rate during the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: During 2024-25, the Weighted Average Call Rate (WACR), on an average, remained 6 basis points above the policy repo rate, compared to 13 bps in the previous year. (Page 95, 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following recent regulatory measures to address potential stress in consumer credit, what is the new risk weight on consumer credit exposure for commercial banks, which was increased from 100 per cent?
questions.explanation: To curb potential build-up of stress, the Reserve Bank raised the risk weights on consumer credit exposure of commercial banks to 125 per cent from the previous 100 per cent. (Page 127)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The weekly borrowing through Treasury Bills in Q3 of FY 2025-26 was expected to be ₹19,000 crore. What is the correct breakdown of this amount across 91 DTBs, 182 DTBs, and 364 DTBs respectively?
questions.explanation: The press release states that the weekly borrowing through issuance of Treasury Bills in Q3 of FY 2025-26 is expected to be ₹19,000 crore with an issuance of ₹7,000 crore under 91 DTBs, ₹6,000 crore under 182 DTBs and ₹6,000 crore under 364 DTBs, respectively.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the analysis of India's post-pandemic recovery using deseasonalised macroeconomic variables, which major variable was identified as still lagging behind its pre-pandemic trend projection as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: The visualisation of key macroeconomic variables reveals that while GDP, GVA, private consumption, GFCF, and industrial GVA have recovered quickly to their pre-pandemic trends, the GVA of the services sector is yet to reach the level projected by its pre-pandemic trend. (Chart I.32, page 62)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In March 2025, the Reserve Bank of India launched the retail pilot of its Central Bank Digital Currency (e₹-R). Across how many cities was this pilot initially launched?
questions.explanation: The RBI took a major step in digital currency adoption by launching the retail pilot of the Central Bank Digital Currency (e₹-R) across 13 cities in March 2025.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The holding period for classifying a capital asset as a 'short-term capital asset' has been amended. What is the new maximum holding period immediately preceding the date of transfer for an asset to be considered short-term?
questions.explanation: Clause 3 of the Bill amends section 2(42A) of the Income-tax Act. It proposes to amend the clause to provide that a 'short-term capital asset' would mean a capital asset held by an assessee for not more than twenty-four months, reducing it from the previous thirty-six months. (Page 33, 162)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The share of floating rate loans in the total gross advances of select scheduled commercial banks increased to what percentage in March 2025?
questions.explanation: The share of floating rate loans in total gross advances for the select banks increased from 72.0 per cent in March 2023 to 75.7 per cent in March 2025. (Source: Page 59, Para 1.59 and Table 1.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In February 2025, the IRDAI increased the Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) limit in the insurance sector. What was the new limit, and what was the previous limit from which it was increased?
questions.explanation: The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI) implemented a major reform in February 2025 by increasing the FDI limit in the insurance sector to 74% from the previous cap of 49%.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected CPI inflation for the financial year 2024-25 according to the Governor's Statement in the October 2024 bulletin?
questions.explanation: Taking into account various factors including food price momentum and global commodity prices, the CPI inflation for 2024-25 is projected at 4.5 per cent, with risks evenly balanced. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new penalty Section 271GC has been inserted for failure to furnish a statement under section 285. What is the penalty if the failure continues for more than three months?
questions.explanation: Section 271GC specifies a penalty for failure to furnish a statement. It is one thousand rupees per day if the failure does not exceed three months, and one lakh rupees in any other case (i.e., if failure exceeds three months). (Page 79, 209)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the year-on-year credit growth of scheduled commercial banks as recorded on June 27, 2025?
questions.explanation: The 'State of the Economy' article mentions that the credit growth of scheduled commercial banks accelerated to 10.4 per cent (y-o-y) as on June 27, 2025, up from 9.9 per cent a month ago. (Page 50)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, which came into effect from August 1, 2025, redefined the threshold of 'substantial interest' from ₹5 lakh to what new amount?
questions.explanation: One of the key amendments in the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, is redefining the threshold of ‘substantial interest’ from ₹5 lakh to ₹2 crore, revising a limit that had remained unchanged since 1968.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For a domestic company with a total income of Rs. 15 crore, what is the applicable rate of surcharge on income tax?
questions.explanation: In the case of every domestic company, a surcharge is calculated at the rate of twelve per cent of such income-tax if the total income exceeds ten crore rupees. (Page 122)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amended Section 2(42A), the holding period for an asset to be a short-term capital asset is now twenty-four months. This amendment takes effect retrospectively. What is the effective date of this change?
questions.explanation: The notes on Clause 3, which amends Section 2(42A), explicitly state at the end, 'This amendment will take effect retrospectively from 23rd July, 2024.' This makes the new 24-month rule applicable from this specific date. (Page 162)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the RBI's quarterly projections for 2024-25, in which quarter is CPI inflation expected to peak?

options.E: Inflation is projected to be constant across all quarters.

questions.explanation: The RBI's projections for CPI inflation in 2024-25 are 4.1% in Q2, 4.8% in Q3, and 4.2% in Q4. The peak inflation is therefore projected for Q3.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the analysis of distributional characteristics of household inflation expectations, which of the following measures were found to be significant with a negative sign, suggesting their utility in predicting one year ahead inflation?

options.E: Standard deviation, Interquartile range, and Skewness

questions.explanation: The model's estimates suggest that measures of dispersion like standard deviation and interquartile range, as well as skewness, are significant with a negative sign in predicting one year ahead inflation, whereas median and mean were found to be not significant. (Page 16, Table I.1.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the surcharge rate applicable to a co-operative society for the assessment year 2025-26 if its total income exceeds ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: In the case of every co-operative society having a total income exceeding ten crore rupees, the surcharge on income-tax is calculated at the rate of twelve per cent. (Page 13, 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for the financial year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: Taking all factors into consideration, the real GDP growth for 2025-26 is projected at 6.5 per cent, with quarterly projections of Q1 at 6.5%, Q2 at 6.7%, Q3 at 6.6% and Q4 at 6.3%. (Page 9, 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the October 2024 Monetary Policy Statement, what is the projected CPI inflation for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Taking into account various factors including food price momentum and global commodity prices, the CPI inflation for 2024-25 is projected at 4.5 per cent. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the real GDP growth projected by the Reserve Bank of India for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: For the current year (2024-25), the Reserve Bank of India has projected real GDP growth of 7.2 per cent, with risks evenly balanced around this forecast. This is supported by improving domestic demand and a strong services sector. (Source: Page 20, 27)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's estimated real GDP growth rate in FY24?
questions.explanation: According to the Economic Survey, India's real GDP grew by 8.2 per cent in FY24, marking the third consecutive year of growth over 7 per cent. This information is stated in the Preface and Chapter 1. (page 8, 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In a move to enhance credit availability for small and marginal farmers, the limit for collateral-free agricultural loans was raised in December 2024. What is the revised limit per borrower?
questions.explanation: Keeping in view the rise in agricultural input costs and overall inflation, the limit for collateral-free agriculture loans was raised from ₹1.6 lakh to ₹2 lakh per borrower in December 2024, effective January 1, 2025. (Page 129, 278)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For which period has a retrospective exemption from service tax been granted for reinsurance services provided by insurance companies under the Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme and Modified National Agricultural Insurance Scheme?
questions.explanation: Clause 130 provides a special retrospective exemption from service tax for reinsurance services under specified schemes for the period commencing from the 1st day of April, 2011 and ending with the 30th day of June, 2017 (both days inclusive). (Page 77, 182)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the first advance estimates by the National Statistics Office (NSO), what was the projected real GDP growth for India for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The first advance estimates (FAE) of national income, released on January 7, 2025, placed the real GDP growth for 2024-25 at 6.4 per cent. This was a moderation from the 8.2 per cent growth recorded a year ago. (Page 9, 16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the theme of the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting held in Davos, Switzerland, in January 2025?

options.E: Stakeholders for a Cohesive and Sustainable World

questions.explanation: The World Economic Forum held in Davos in January 2025 adopted the theme 'Rebuilding Trust', where India's Prime Minister highlighted the country's growth story.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) of the Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFC) sector as of September 2023?
questions.explanation: The CRAR of NBFCs stood at 27.6 per cent in September 2023, which is well above the regulatory minimum of 15 per cent, indicating substantial capital buffers. (Page 19, 71)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average headline CPI inflation rate during the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Headline inflation moderated to an average of 4.6 per cent during 2024-25 from 5.4 per cent in the previous year. (Page 30, 59)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In which month of 2024 did the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decide to change its policy stance from 'withdrawal of accommodation' to 'neutral'?
questions.explanation: Buoyed by a well-balanced inflation-growth dynamics, the MPC unanimously decided in its October 2024 meeting to change the policy stance from withdrawal of accommodation to neutral to provide it the flexibility to monitor the progress of ongoing disinflation. (Page 114)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For resident individuals aged eighty years or more, what is the basic exemption limit for income tax for the assessment year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: For resident individuals aged eighty years or more (super senior citizens), the basic exemption limit where no income tax is charged is up to Rs. 5,00,000. (Page 82)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following service sub-sectors, being contact-intensive, had not yet surpassed its pre-pandemic trend level by the first half of FY25?

options.A: Financial, real estate and professional services
options.B: Public administration, defence, and other services
options.C: Trade, hotels, transport, and communication services

questions.explanation: The recovery within the services sector has been uneven. While financial services and public administration surpassed pre-pandemic trend levels, 'trade, hotels, transport, and communication services' are still gradually catching up with the pre-pandemic trend. (Page 57, Para 1.27 & Chart I.26)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) for 2022-23, what percentage of the total workforce is employed in agriculture?
questions.explanation: As per the PLFS, more than 45 per cent (specifically 45.8% as shown in Chart VIII.3) of the workforce is employed in agriculture, highlighting its predominance in providing employment. (Page 321)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance (No. 2) Bill, 2024, introduced a new scheme for the resolution of direct tax disputes. What is this scheme named?

options.B: The Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024
options.D: The Direct Tax Dispute Resolution Scheme, 2024
options.E: The Direct Tax Kar Samadhan Scheme, 2024

questions.explanation: Chapter IV of the Finance (No. 2) Bill, 2024, is titled 'THE DIRECT TAX VIVAD SE VISHWAS SCHEME, 2024'. Section 88(1) states, 'This Scheme may be called the Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024.' (Page 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new clause (12BA) in Section 10 allows tax exemption on partial withdrawal from a minor's National Pension System account. What is the maximum percentage of contributions made by the parent/guardian that can be withdrawn tax-free?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted clause (12BA) in Section 10 provides that any payment from the NPS Trust on partial withdrawal from a minor's account is exempt to the extent it does not exceed twenty-five per cent of the contributions made. (Page 36, 141)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: India witnessed a robust inflow of Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI) in FY24. What was the total value of net FPI inflows during this period?
questions.explanation: Net FPI inflows stood at USD 44.1 billion during FY24, a significant turnaround from the net outflows in the preceding two years, which helped fund the CAD. (Page 75)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The government increased the deposit insurance coverage to ₹10 lakh in April 2025. This move, combined with the RBI's introduction of stricter norms for unsecured personal loans in February 2025, suggests a regulatory focus on what two key aspects of the banking sector?

options.A: Encouraging higher FDI and promoting global banking mergers.
options.B: Expanding bank nationalization and increasing government control.
options.C: Boosting credit card usage and simplifying loan recovery processes.
options.D: Enhancing depositor confidence and mitigating risks from rapid credit growth.
options.E: Reducing the number of public sector banks and increasing priority sector lending targets.

questions.explanation: Increasing deposit insurance directly enhances the confidence of depositors in the banking system, assuring them of their savings' safety. Simultaneously, introducing stricter norms for unsecured loans, which are inherently riskier, is a measure to mitigate potential systemic risks arising from unchecked growth in this segment. The two actions together show a focus on financial stability by protecting depositors and controlling credit risk.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for India for the fiscal year 2024-25, as stated by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC)?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) has projected India's real GDP to grow by 7.2 per cent during 2024-25. This follows a real GDP growth of 8.2 per cent in 2023-24. (Page 34)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In May 2025, India achieved a major economic milestone by surpassing Japan to become the world's third-largest economy. What was India's approximate GDP size at that point?
questions.explanation: In May 2025, India's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) reached $4.5 trillion, which led to it surpassing Japan and becoming the third-largest economy in the world.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: India's foreign exchange reserves reached an all-time high in September 2025, touching which specific figure?
questions.explanation: According to the provided data for September 2025, India's forex reserves reached a new all-time high of $720 billion.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the majority vote in the August 2024 MPC meeting to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent?
questions.explanation: The report states that in the August 2024 meeting, the MPC decided by a majority of 4-2 to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Ways and Means Advances (WMA) limit fixed by the Reserve Bank of India for the second half of FY 2025-26?
questions.explanation: According to the Government's borrowing plan for H2 of FY 2025-26, the Reserve Bank of India fixed the Ways and Mean Advances (WMA) limit at ₹50,000 crore to manage temporary mismatches in Government payments and receipts.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The key provisions of the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, which came into effect from 1st August 2025, redefined the threshold of 'substantial interest' from ₹5 lakh to what new amount?
questions.explanation: One of the key amendments in the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, is redefining the threshold of 'substantial interest' from ₹5 lakh to ₹2 crore, revising a limit that had been unchanged since 1968.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the macro stress tests, what is the projected Gross NPA (GNPA) ratio for all Scheduled Commercial Banks by March 2025 in a severe stress scenario?
questions.explanation: While the GNPA ratio of all SCBs is projected to improve to 2.5 per cent by March 2025 under the baseline scenario, it may rise to 3.4 per cent if the macroeconomic environment worsens to a severe stress scenario. (Page 86)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the analysis of liquidity drivers in FY 2024-25, which of the following was the largest single factor contributing to the withdrawal of liquidity from the banking system?

options.A: Build-up of Government of India Cash Balances
options.C: Build-up of Excess Reserves by banks
options.D: Net Forex Sales by the RBI

questions.explanation: As per Table III.1 on 'Liquidity – Key Drivers and Management', Net Forex Sales led to a liquidity withdrawal of ₹2,91,233 crore in FY 2024-25, which was larger than the withdrawal due to Currency in Circulation (₹2,04,703 crore). (Page 117)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the level of capacity utilisation (CU) in the manufacturing sector during Q3:2024-25?
questions.explanation: Capacity utilisation (CU) in the manufacturing sector increased to 75.4 per cent in Q3:2024-25 from 74.7 per cent in the same quarter of the previous year. (Page 51)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the financial soundness parameters for December 2024, which of the following statements correctly compares the performance of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) and Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs)?

options.A: The Capital to Risk Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for SCBs was higher than that for NBFCs.
options.B: The Return on Assets (RoA) for SCBs was higher than that for NBFCs.
options.C: NBFCs had a lower Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio than SCBs.
options.D: NBFCs had a higher Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio than SCBs.
options.E: Both SCBs and NBFCs reported a Return on Assets (RoA) below 1%.

questions.explanation: As per the data in the footnotes, in December 2024, the GNPA ratio for NBFCs was 2.53%, while for SCBs it was 2.42%. Therefore, the GNPA ratio of NBFCs was higher than that of SCBs. The CRAR for NBFCs (26.22%) was higher than SCBs (16.43%), and the RoA for NBFCs (2.86%) was higher than SCBs (1.37%). (Page 11, footnotes 23 & 26)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance Bill extends the date of investment for specified persons like sovereign wealth funds and pension funds to claim exemption on certain incomes under section 10(23FE). What is the new deadline by which such investments must be made?
questions.explanation: Clause 6(g) of the Bill amends sub-clause (i) of clause (23FE) of section 10, extending the date of investment for specified persons from '2025' to '2030'. Therefore, the investment must be made on or before 31st March, 2030. (Page 37, Page 142)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following correctly matches the RBI's recent regulatory/supervisory initiative with its primary objective?

options.A: PRAVAAH: To manage liquidity through open market operations.
options.B: sDQI (Supervisory Data Quality Index): To assess and improve the quality of risk data reporting by supervised entities.
options.C: RB-CRIS (Climate Risk Information System): To provide a platform for reporting of financial frauds.
options.D: SAKAR Framework: To facilitate the transition of Small Finance Banks to Universal Banks.
options.E: FinTech Repository: To manage the RBI's internal employee data and HR functions.

questions.explanation: The Supervisory Data Quality Index (sDQI) was developed to identify and address deficiencies in risk data aggregation capabilities and risk reporting practices across Supervised Entities (SEs). The other options are mismatched: PRAVAAH is for regulatory applications, RB-CRIS is for climate risk data, SAKAR is for KYC/AML risk assessment, and FinTech Repository is for capturing information on FinTech entities. (Page 34, 40, 126, 141, 146)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate maintained by the Monetary Policy Committee in its meetings between October 2023 and February 2024?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.50 per cent through H2:2023-24 to align inflation with the target while supporting growth. (Page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question:
With reference to the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, which of the following provisions were among those that came into effect from 1st August 2025?
I. Redefining the threshold of ‘substantial interest’ from ₹5 lakh to ₹2 crore.
II. Permitting Public Sector Banks to transfer unclaimed shares and bond redemption amounts to the Investor Education and Protection Fund (IEPF).
III. Increasing the maximum tenure of cooperative bank directors (excluding the chairperson and whole-time director) from 8 years to 10 years.
questions.explanation: The press release on the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, explicitly mentions that the provisions which came into force on 1st August 2025 include redefining 'substantial interest' to ₹2 crore, allowing PSBs to transfer unclaimed amounts to the IEPF, and increasing the tenure of cooperative bank directors to 10 years.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected range for India's real GDP growth in FY26?
questions.explanation: On balance of considerations regarding robust domestic fundamentals and global headwinds, the survey expects that the growth in FY26 would be between 6.3 and 6.8 per cent. (Page 78, Para 1.73)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As announced in the Union Budget 2025, what is the revised Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) cap proposed for the Insurance sector?
questions.explanation: Footnote 1 on page 7 explicitly states that as announced in the Union Budget 2025, the FDI cap in the Insurance sector will rise to 100 per cent, with the condition that the entire premium is invested within India. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the macro stress tests, what is the projected Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks by March 2027 under the 'Geopolitical risk scenario' (Adverse Scenario 1)?
questions.explanation: The macro stress test projects that the aggregate GNPA ratio of 46 major banks may rise from 2.3% in March 2025 to 5.6% by March 2027 under Adverse Scenario 1, which represents a geopolitical risk scenario. (Page 84, Chart 2.11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The services sector growth in FY25 is expected to remain robust. What is the estimated growth rate for the sector?
questions.explanation: Growth in the services sector is expected to remain robust at 7.2 per cent in FY25, driven by healthy activity in various sub-sectors. (Page 57)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the total amount of gold held by the Reserve Bank of India as of March 31, 2024?
questions.explanation: As on March 31, 2024, the total gold held by the Reserve Bank was 822.10 metric tonnes, an increase from 794.63 metric tonnes on March 31, 2023. (Page 261, Para ii and Table XII.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the Direct Tax Vivad se Vishwas Scheme, 2024, for an appellant who filed after January 31, 2020, where the tax arrear includes disputed tax, interest, and penalty, what is the amount payable if the payment is made on or before December 31, 2024?

options.A: The amount of the disputed tax
options.E: The aggregate of disputed tax and 10% of disputed tax

questions.explanation: As per the Table under section 90, for a case where the tax arrear is the aggregate amount of disputed tax, interest, and penalty, and the declarant is an appellant after 31st Jan 2020, the amount payable on or before Dec 31, 2024, is simply the 'Amount of the disputed tax'. (Page 84)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of June 2025, what percentage of India's installed power capacity was accounted for by non-fossil fuel sources, achieving a major energy transition target five years ahead of schedule?
questions.explanation: The document states that as of June 2025, non-fossil fuel sources accounted for 50.1 per cent of India’s installed power capacity. This achieved the Nationally Determined Contributions target of around 50 per cent by 2030, five years ahead of schedule. (Page 43, Chart III.9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Union Budget 2025-26, what fiscal deficit target was set for the financial year 2025-26 as a percentage of GDP?
questions.explanation: The Union Budget presented in January 2025 set India's fiscal deficit target at 4.9% of GDP for the financial year 2025-26, indicating a path of fiscal consolidation.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the final quarter of the financial year 2024-25, India's current account balance recorded a surplus. What was the value of this surplus?
questions.explanation: The section on Balance of Payments in the 'State of the Economy' article states that India’s current account balance recorded a surplus of US$ 13.5 billion (1.3 per cent of GDP) in Q4:2024-25. (Page 54)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For an individual whose income is chargeable under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC), and whose total income includes dividends, what is the maximum rate of surcharge on the income-tax computed on that dividend income?

options.E: The normal applicable surcharge rate without any cap

questions.explanation: A proviso to the surcharge rules for Section 115BAC states that if the total income includes any income by way of dividend or income chargeable under sections 111A, 112, and 112A, the rate of surcharge on the income-tax in respect of that part of income shall not exceed fifteen per cent. (Page 17)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During its meeting from June 4-6, 2025, what did the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decide to set the policy repo rate at?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to reduce the policy repo rate by 50 basis points to 5.50 per cent with immediate effect. (Page 7, Page 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In a scenario where global growth turns out to be 100 bps lower than the baseline assumption, what is the estimated consequential impact on India's domestic growth and inflation, respectively?
questions.explanation: Under the Global Growth Uncertainties risk scenario, if global growth is 100 bps lower than baseline, domestic growth could be lower by around 30 bps and inflation could be lower by around 15 bps. (page 21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth projected at for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Real gross domestic product (GDP) for India is projected to grow at 6.6 per cent in 2024-25, supported by a revival in rural consumption and strong services exports. (Page 24)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth rate in 2024-25, according to the Second Advance Estimates?
questions.explanation: Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth moderated to 6.5 per cent in 2024-25, as per the Second Advance Estimates (SAE) of National Income. (Page 29, 43)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the financial stability assessment, which of the following sets of parameters for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of June 2025 is correctly reported?
questions.explanation: Footnote 29 on page 11 provides the key parameters for SCBs as of June 2025: the GNPA ratio was 2.24 per cent, the NNPA Ratio was 0.53 per cent, and the Capital to Risk Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) was 17.44 per cent. The other options either use data from June 2024 or mix SCB data with NBFC data.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the macro stress tests for Scheduled Commercial Banks, what is the projected aggregate GNPA ratio by March 2026 under the severe 'adverse scenario 2'?
questions.explanation: The macro stress tests project that the aggregate GNPA ratio of the 46 select banks may rise from 2.6 per cent in September 2024 to 5.3 per cent by March 2026 under the severe 'adverse scenario 2'. (Page 91)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the Monetary Policy Committee meeting in April 2025, what was the new policy repo rate set at?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points to 6.00 per cent with immediate effect. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the contagion analysis conducted in March 2024, what would be the estimated impact if the Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses were to fail?

options.A: A 2.29% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and the failure of one bank.
options.B: A 2.29% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and no subsequent bank failures.
options.C: A 3.87% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and no subsequent bank failures.
options.D: A 3.87% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and the failure of one bank.
options.E: A 5.06% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and no subsequent bank failures.

questions.explanation: The solvency contagion analysis showed that the hypothetical failure of the top NBFC would result in a 2.29 per cent loss of the banking system's total Tier 1 capital, but it would not lead to the failure of any bank. The 3.87% figure corresponds to an HFC failure. (Page 116)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question:
The Indian banking sector has undergone significant reforms in recent decades, aimed at improving efficiency, stability, and competitiveness. These reforms include deregulation of interest rates, reduction in statutory reserve requirements, and the introduction of stricter prudential norms. The establishment of asset reconstruction companies has helped to address the issue of non-performing assets. Furthermore, the government has taken steps to consolidate public sector banks to enhance their operational efficiency and financial strength. However, challenges remain, including the need to further improve asset quality, strengthen risk management practices, and adapt to the evolving landscape of digital banking. Continuous innovation and regulatory vigilance are crucial for the sustained growth and stability of the Indian banking system.

What is the primary purpose of consolidating public sector banks, as mentioned in the passage?

options.A: To reduce the number of bank branches in rural areas
options.B: To decrease the overall lending capacity of the banking sector
options.C: To enhance their operational efficiency and financial strength
options.D: To increase the government's control over the banking system
options.E: To promote the privatization of public sector banks

questions.explanation: The passage states that the government has taken steps to consolidate public sector banks to enhance their operational efficiency and financial strength. The other options are not the primary reasons for consolidation as described in the passage.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
International banking and finance involve the flow of capital, goods, and services across national borders. This includes activities such as foreign direct investment, international trade, and currency exchange. Multinational corporations play a significant role in international banking and finance by investing in foreign countries and engaging in cross-border transactions. The global financial system is interconnected, and events in one country can have ripple effects on other countries. International financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund, IMF, and the World Bank play a crucial role in promoting global financial stability and economic development. Fluctuations in exchange rates and interest rates can significantly impact international trade and investment flows.

According to the passage, what role do international financial institutions like the IMF play?

options.B: To promote global financial stability and economic development.
options.E: To manage the fiscal policy of individual countries.

questions.explanation: The passage states that international financial institutions such as the IMF and the World Bank play a crucial role in promoting global financial stability and economic development.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The Reserve Bank of India, RBI, plays a crucial role in managing inflation through its monetary policy. The primary objective is to maintain price stability while supporting economic growth. The RBI uses various tools such as the repo rate, reverse repo rate, and cash reserve ratio to control the money supply in the economy. When inflation rises, the RBI typically increases the repo rate, making it more expensive for commercial banks to borrow money. This, in turn, leads to higher lending rates for consumers and businesses, which reduces demand and helps to curb inflation. The effectiveness of the RBI's monetary policy depends on several factors, including the fiscal policy of the government and global economic conditions.

What is the main function of the RBI as described in the passage?

options.C: To manage inflation and support economic growth.
options.E: To set interest rates for consumers directly.

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that the RBI's primary objective is to maintain price stability (manage inflation) while supporting economic growth.
questions.subject: English

questions.question: (A) The central bank's recent announcement / (B) regarding a marginal adjustment in the cash reserve ratio / (C), along with its cautious outlook on inflation, / (D) have significantly influenced market sentiment.
questions.explanation: In part (D), the verb 'have' is incorrect. The subject of the sentence is 'announcement' (singular), not 'cash reserve ratio' or 'outlook'. The phrase 'along with its cautious outlook on inflation' is an additive phrase, not part of the compound subject, and therefore does not affect the number of the verb. The verb should agree with the singular subject 'announcement'. Thus, 'have' should be 'has'. The corrected sentence would be: 'The central bank's recent announcement regarding a marginal adjustment in the cash reserve ratio, along with its cautious outlook on inflation, has significantly influenced market sentiment.'
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Choose the word CLOSEST in meaning to the word 'OBFUSCATE' as used in the given sentence.

The central bank's communication strategy should aim for transparency rather than attempting to **obfuscate** the true state of inflation.
questions.explanation: The word 'obfuscate' means to make something unclear, confusing, or difficult to understand. In the context of a central bank's communication, it refers to making the economic situation harder for the public to comprehend. Options A, B, and E ('Elucidate', 'Clarify', 'Simplify') are antonyms, meaning to make clear or explain. Option C ('Conceal') implies hiding something entirely, while 'obfuscate' is more about making it ambiguous or perplexing rather than completely hidden. 'Obscure' (D) is the closest synonym, meaning to make something difficult to see, hear, or understand, precisely fitting the nuanced meaning of obfuscate in this sentence.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The Reserve Bank of India, RBI, plays a crucial role in managing inflation through its monetary policy. The primary tool used is the manipulation of the repo rate, the rate at which commercial banks borrow money from the RBI. When inflation rises, the RBI typically increases the repo rate. This makes borrowing more expensive for banks, which in turn increases lending rates for businesses and consumers. Consequently, demand decreases, leading to a cooling down of prices. However, this approach can also slow down economic growth. The RBI must carefully balance controlling inflation with supporting economic expansion to maintain overall financial stability. Factors such as global commodity prices and monsoon patterns also influence inflation, making the RBI's task complex and multifaceted. Understanding these dynamics is vital for effective monetary policy implementation.

What is the most likely consequence of the RBI increasing the repo rate?
questions.explanation: An increased repo rate makes borrowing more expensive, leading to decreased demand and lower inflation. The other options describe the opposite effect or are unrelated.
questions.subject: English

questions.question: (A) The monetary policy committee emphasized / (B) that central banks across the globe / (C) must maintain its independence / (D) from political interference to ensure effective governance.
questions.explanation: In part (C), the possessive pronoun 'its' is incorrect. The pronoun 'its' is singular, but the antecedent it refers to is 'central banks across the globe', which is plural. Therefore, the plural possessive pronoun 'their' should be used instead of 'its'. The corrected sentence would be: 'The monetary policy committee emphasized that central banks across the globe must maintain their independence from political interference to ensure effective governance.'
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The Reserve Bank of India employs various instruments to manage inflation, primarily through its monetary policy. The repo rate, the rate at which commercial banks borrow money from the RBI, is a key tool. Increasing the repo rate makes borrowing more expensive, reducing the money supply and curbing demand-pull inflation. Conversely, decreasing the repo rate encourages borrowing, increasing the money supply and potentially stimulating economic growth. The cash reserve ratio, the percentage of deposits banks must hold with the RBI, also plays a role. A higher CRR reduces the amount of money banks can lend, while a lower CRR increases their lending capacity. Open market operations, involving the buying and selling of government securities, are another important instrument. Buying securities injects liquidity into the market, while selling securities withdraws liquidity. Effective inflation management requires a delicate balance to avoid stifling economic growth.

What is the primary objective of the RBI when adjusting the repo rate?

options.A: To directly control the fiscal deficit of the government
options.B: To influence the lending behavior of commercial banks and manage inflation
options.C: To regulate the stock market and ensure its stability
options.D: To promote foreign direct investment in the country
options.E: To directly increase the profitability of commercial banks

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that the repo rate is used to manage inflation by influencing the lending behavior of commercial banks. Options A, C, D, and E are not related to the repo rate's primary function as described in the passage.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Choose the word OPPOSITE in meaning to the word 'SANGUINE' as used in the given sentence.

Despite the recent market volatility, the analyst remained **sanguine** about the long-term prospects of the banking sector.
questions.explanation: The word 'sanguine' means optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently difficult or challenging situation. The analyst's outlook is positive despite market volatility. Options A, B, C, and E ('Optimistic', 'Buoyant', 'Hopeful', 'Confident') are all synonyms or closely related in meaning to 'sanguine'. The exact opposite of being optimistic or positive is being 'Pessimistic' (D), which means tending to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen. This perfectly captures the contrasting sentiment.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The Indian banking system has undergone significant reforms in recent decades. These reforms aimed to improve the efficiency, stability, and competitiveness of the banking sector. Key reforms include the introduction of stricter capital adequacy norms, the strengthening of regulatory oversight, and the promotion of competition among banks. The implementation of Basel III norms has enhanced the resilience of banks to financial shocks. Furthermore, the adoption of technology has transformed the banking landscape, with the rise of digital banking and fintech companies. However, challenges such as rising non-performing assets and the need for further consolidation remain.

What is one of the main goals of the reforms in the Indian banking system according to the passage?

options.C: To improve the efficiency and stability of the banking sector.

questions.explanation: The passage states that the reforms aimed to improve the efficiency, stability, and competitiveness of the banking sector.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a widely used measure of inflation that tracks the average change in prices paid by urban consumers for a basket of goods and services. It is used to monitor inflation trends and adjust wages, salaries, and government benefits. The CPI is calculated by collecting data on the prices of various items, weighting them according to their importance in the average consumer's budget, and then computing the percentage change in the weighted average price over time. Changes in the CPI can have a significant impact on the economy, influencing interest rates, investment decisions, and consumer spending.

What does the CPI measure, according to the passage?

options.C: Average change in prices paid by urban consumers

questions.explanation: The passage defines the CPI as a measure of the average change in prices paid by urban consumers.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Microfinance institutions play a crucial role in providing financial services to low-income individuals and small businesses, particularly in rural areas. These institutions offer small loans, savings accounts, and other financial products that are often inaccessible through traditional banks. While microfinance has been successful in empowering many people, it also faces challenges such as high interest rates, over-indebtedness, and regulatory oversight. Ensuring the sustainability and ethical practices of microfinance institutions is essential to maximize their positive impact and minimize potential risks. Furthermore, promoting financial literacy among borrowers is crucial to enable them to make informed decisions and manage their finances effectively.

What is a significant challenge faced by microfinance institutions, as mentioned in the passage?

options.A: Low demand for financial services in rural areas
options.B: High interest rates charged by microfinance institutions
options.C: Excessive government regulation of the sector
options.D: Lack of skilled personnel in the banking industry
options.E: Limited access to technology for financial transactions

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly mentions that high interest rates are a challenge faced by microfinance institutions. The other options are not directly identified as challenges in the passage.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Choose the word CLOSEST in meaning to the word 'PERVASIVE' as used in the given sentence.

The **pervasive** influence of digital transformation is reshaping traditional banking operations globally.
questions.explanation: The word 'pervasive' means spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people, or existing in every part of something. Here, it describes the widespread and comprehensive impact of digital transformation. Options A, B, and D ('Confined', 'Sporadic', 'Isolated') are antonyms, suggesting limited or infrequent presence. 'Incidental' (E) means occurring as a minor accompaniment or by chance, which doesn't fit the strong and widespread influence described. 'Prevalent' (C) means widespread in a particular area or at a particular time; it is the closest synonym to 'pervasive', indicating a widespread and common presence.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Non-Performing Assets, NPAs, pose a significant challenge to the Indian banking sector. These are loans where borrowers have stopped making interest or principal payments for a specified period. High levels of NPAs erode bank profitability, reduce lending capacity, and can threaten financial stability. Several factors contribute to the accumulation of NPAs, including economic slowdowns, project delays, and willful loan defaults. The Reserve Bank of India has implemented various measures to address the NPA problem, such as asset quality reviews and restructuring schemes. Effective management of NPAs is crucial for maintaining the health and resilience of the banking system.

What is the primary consequence of high levels of Non-Performing Assets for banks?
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that high levels of NPAs erode bank profitability. The other options describe the opposite effect or are unrelated.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Choose the word OPPOSITE in meaning to the word 'STRINGENT' as used in the given sentence.

To prevent financial crises, regulatory bodies have imposed **stringent** capital requirements on banks.
questions.explanation: The word 'stringent' means strict, precise, and exacting. In the financial context, it refers to tough and uncompromising rules or requirements. Options A, B, D, and E ('Rigorous', 'Exacting', 'Demanding', 'Uncompromising') are all synonyms or very closely related in meaning to 'stringent'. The direct opposite of being strict or tough is being lenient or relaxed. 'Lax' (C) means not sufficiently strict, severe, or careful, which perfectly captures the antonym of 'stringent' in this regulatory context.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Financial inclusion is a critical aspect of economic development. It ensures that all individuals and businesses, regardless of their income level, have access to affordable and usable financial services. These services include banking, insurance, and credit facilities. Digital banking plays a significant role in promoting financial inclusion by reducing the cost of delivering financial services and expanding their reach to remote areas. Government initiatives such as the Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana have also contributed significantly to increasing the number of people with bank accounts. However, challenges such as low financial literacy and limited access to internet connectivity remain.

According to the passage, what is a significant factor contributing to financial inclusion?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that digital banking and government initiatives like Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana have significantly contributed to financial inclusion.
questions.subject: English

questions.question: (A) Financial institutions are now mandated / (B) to strictly adhere with the new cybersecurity protocols / (C) stipulated by regulatory bodies / (D) to safeguard customer data.
questions.explanation: In part (B), the preposition 'with' is incorrectly used after the verb 'adhere'. The verb 'adhere' typically takes the preposition 'to' when it means 'to stick firmly to a belief, system, or plan'. Therefore, 'adhere with' should be 'adhere to'. The corrected sentence would be: 'Financial institutions are now mandated to strictly adhere to the new cybersecurity protocols stipulated by regulatory bodies to safeguard customer data.'
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Economic indicators provide valuable insights into the health and performance of an economy. Key indicators include gross domestic product, GDP, inflation rate, unemployment rate, and interest rates. GDP measures the total value of goods and services produced in a country. A high GDP growth rate indicates a strong and expanding economy. The inflation rate measures the rate at which prices are rising. High inflation can erode purchasing power and destabilize the economy. The unemployment rate measures the percentage of the labor force that is unemployed. High unemployment can lead to social and economic problems. Central banks use these indicators to make informed decisions about monetary policy.

According to the passage, what does a high GDP growth rate indicate?
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that a high GDP growth rate indicates a strong and expanding economy.
questions.subject: English

questions.question: (A) Despite the sustained efforts by the RBI / (B) to stabilize the currency in recent months, / (C) the market volatility has been persisted / (D) due to external economic pressures.
questions.explanation: In part (C), the verb phrase 'has been persisted' is grammatically incorrect. The verb 'persist' is typically intransitive, meaning it does not take a direct object and cannot usually be used in the passive voice. Volatility itself 'persists' or 'has persisted'. The correct active voice present perfect form should be used here. Thus, 'has been persisted' should be 'has persisted'. The corrected sentence would be: 'Despite the sustained efforts by the RBI to stabilize the currency in recent months, the market volatility has persisted due to external economic pressures.'
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The global financial crisis of 2008 highlighted the interconnectedness of financial markets and the importance of robust risk management practices. The crisis originated in the United States with the collapse of the subprime mortgage market and quickly spread to other countries, causing widespread economic disruption. Banks experienced significant losses, credit markets froze, and many businesses faced bankruptcy. Governments and central banks intervened with massive bailouts and monetary easing measures to stabilize the financial system. The crisis led to increased regulation of the financial industry and a greater focus on preventing future crises. International cooperation is essential for addressing systemic risks and promoting global financial stability.

What was a key factor that contributed to the global financial crisis of 2008?

options.C: The collapse of the subprime mortgage market in the United States
options.D: A decrease in global interest rates

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that the crisis originated in the United States with the collapse of the subprime mortgage market. The other options are not mentioned as key contributing factors.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Basel III is an international regulatory framework designed to strengthen the resilience of the banking system by enhancing capital adequacy, liquidity, and risk management. It addresses the shortcomings identified during the 2008 financial crisis. The framework introduces stricter capital requirements, including higher minimum capital ratios and a capital conservation buffer. It also establishes liquidity standards, such as the Liquidity Coverage Ratio and the Net Stable Funding Ratio, to ensure that banks have sufficient liquid assets to meet short-term and long-term funding needs. Implementation of Basel III has been phased in over several years, and it continues to shape banking regulations globally.

According to the passage, what is the purpose of Basel III?

options.C: To strengthen the resilience of the banking system
options.D: To encourage lending to small businesses

questions.explanation: The passage clearly states that Basel III is designed to strengthen the resilience of the banking system.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The concept of moral suasion is often employed by central banks, including the Reserve Bank of India, as a tool to influence the behavior of commercial banks. It involves the central bank using persuasive techniques, rather than formal regulations, to encourage banks to comply with its policy objectives. This might include public statements, private meetings, or informal guidance. Moral suasion is most effective when the central bank has a strong reputation and a good relationship with the commercial banks. However, its effectiveness can be limited if banks have conflicting incentives or if the central bank lacks credibility. It is a subtle tool and its impact is often difficult to quantify.

What is the central idea behind the use of moral suasion by central banks?

options.A: Enforcing strict regulations on commercial banks.
options.B: Using persuasive techniques to influence bank behavior.
options.C: Ignoring the policy objectives of commercial banks.
options.D: Quantifying the impact of monetary policy.
options.E: Directly controlling interest rates for all banks.

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that moral suasion involves the central bank using persuasive techniques, rather than formal regulations, to encourage banks to comply with its policy objectives.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Financial inclusion is a critical aspect of economic development, aiming to provide access to affordable financial services to all segments of society, especially the underserved and vulnerable. Digital banking has emerged as a powerful tool for promoting financial inclusion, offering convenient and cost-effective ways to reach remote areas and lower-income populations. Initiatives like Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana have played a significant role in expanding access to banking services. However, challenges remain, including low financial literacy, lack of internet access in some regions, and concerns about cybersecurity. Overcoming these hurdles is essential to fully realize the potential of digital banking in furthering financial inclusion and promoting inclusive growth.

What is identified as a major challenge to financial inclusion?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions low financial literacy as one of the challenges hindering the progress of financial inclusion.
questions.subject: English

questions.question: To enhance operational efficiency and customer experience, the bank decided to ______ the process of opening new savings accounts through a fully digital KYC mechanism.
questions.explanation: The sentence indicates that the bank wants to improve efficiency and customer experience by using a digital mechanism. The word that means to make a process happen sooner or more quickly is 'expedite'. 'Obstruct', 'hinder', 'delay', and 'protract' all mean to slow down, impede, or prolong a process, which is contrary to the stated goal of enhancing efficiency. Thus, 'expedite' is the most suitable word.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The Reserve Bank of India, as the central bank, plays a crucial role in managing the nation's money supply and credit. Its primary objective is to maintain price stability while fostering economic growth. The RBI employs various instruments like the repo rate, reverse repo rate, and cash reserve ratio to influence the liquidity in the banking system. Changes in these rates impact the cost of borrowing for banks, which in turn affects lending rates for businesses and individuals. A tight monetary policy, characterized by higher interest rates, aims to curb inflation by reducing demand, while an accommodative policy seeks to stimulate economic activity through lower interest rates. The effectiveness of monetary policy depends on several factors, including the responsiveness of businesses and consumers to interest rate changes and the overall economic outlook.

What is the main goal of the RBI according to the passage?

options.C: To maintain price stability and foster economic growth

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that the RBI's primary objective is to maintain price stability while fostering economic growth.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Basel III is a comprehensive set of reform measures, developed by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, to strengthen the regulation, supervision, and risk management of banks. It aims to improve the banking sector's ability to absorb shocks arising from financial stress, improve risk management and governance, and strengthen banks' transparency and disclosures. Key elements of Basel III include higher minimum capital requirements, stricter liquidity standards, and measures to reduce procyclicality. The implementation of Basel III has been phased in over several years and has had a significant impact on the global banking landscape. While it has enhanced the stability of the banking system, it has also increased compliance costs for banks and may have contributed to a slight reduction in lending activity.

What is the primary goal of Basel III, as described in the passage?

options.A: To reduce the profitability of the banking sector
options.B: To promote greater competition among banks
options.C: To strengthen the regulation, supervision, and risk management of banks
options.D: To encourage banks to increase their lending activity
options.E: To simplify the accounting standards used by banks

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that Basel III aims to strengthen the regulation, supervision, and risk management of banks. The other options are not the primary goals of Basel III as described in the passage.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Choose the word CLOSEST in meaning to the word 'AMELIORATE' as used in the given sentence.

The government introduced new fiscal policies designed to **ameliorate** the economic hardship faced by low-income households.
questions.explanation: The word 'ameliorate' means to make something bad or unsatisfactory better or more tolerable. In the context, the fiscal policies aim to improve the difficult economic situation. Options A, B, C, and D ('Exacerbate', 'Aggravate', 'Intensify', 'Worsen') are all antonyms, meaning to make a problem or situation worse. 'Alleviate' (E) is the closest synonym, as it means to make suffering, deficiency, or a problem less severe, which directly aligns with the goal of improving economic hardship.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
The global economy is facing a complex interplay of factors, including rising inflation, supply chain disruptions, and geopolitical uncertainties. Central banks around the world are grappling with the challenge of tightening monetary policy to control inflation without triggering a recession. The war in Ukraine has exacerbated supply chain issues and pushed up energy prices. Furthermore, the resurgence of COVID-19 in some regions continues to disrupt economic activity. These factors are contributing to a slowdown in global growth and increased volatility in financial markets. International cooperation is essential to address these challenges and promote sustainable and inclusive growth.

According to the passage, what is a major factor contributing to the slowdown in global growth?

options.A: Decreasing interest rates by central banks
options.B: Increased government spending on infrastructure projects
options.C: The resurgence of COVID-19 in some regions

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly mentions that the resurgence of COVID-19 in some regions continues to disrupt economic activity, contributing to a slowdown in global growth. The other options are not presented as factors contributing to the slowdown.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Financial inclusion aims to extend banking services to the unbanked and underbanked populations. This involves providing access to basic banking accounts, credit, insurance, and other financial products at an affordable cost. Initiatives like the Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana have significantly increased the number of bank accounts, but ensuring their active usage remains a challenge. Digital banking channels, such as mobile banking and internet banking, are playing a crucial role in expanding financial inclusion, particularly in remote areas. However, digital literacy and internet access are essential prerequisites. Furthermore, addressing issues like cybersecurity and fraud prevention is vital to maintain trust in digital financial services. The ultimate goal is to empower individuals and communities by enabling them to participate more fully in the formal financial system.

According to the passage, what is a significant challenge in achieving effective financial inclusion despite the increase in bank accounts?

options.A: The lack of government subsidies for banking services
options.B: The active usage of newly opened bank accounts
options.C: The high interest rates charged by commercial banks
options.D: The limited availability of banking infrastructure in urban areas
options.E: The reluctance of people to open bank accounts

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly mentions that ensuring the active usage of newly opened bank accounts remains a challenge despite the increase in their numbers. The other options are not directly addressed in the passage as primary challenges.
questions.subject: English

questions.question:
Government schemes play a vital role in addressing various socio-economic challenges in India. These schemes aim to improve the living standards of citizens, promote economic growth, and reduce inequality. Some of the key schemes include the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, MGNREGA, which provides employment to rural households, the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana, PMAY, which aims to provide affordable housing, and the Ayushman Bharat scheme, which provides health insurance coverage. The success of these schemes depends on effective implementation, adequate funding, and proper monitoring. Challenges such as corruption and leakages can hinder their effectiveness.

What is the primary goal of the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY) as mentioned in the passage?

options.A: To provide employment to rural households.

questions.explanation: The passage states that the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY) aims to provide affordable housing.
questions.subject: English

questions.question: A company had a revenue of $1,000,000 last year. This year, the revenue increased by 8%, but expenses increased by 12%. If the expenses last year were $600,000, what is the percentage change in profit?
questions.explanation: Last year's profit was \(1000000 - 600000 = 400000\). This year, revenue is \(1000000 \times 1.08 = 1080000\) and expenses are \(600000 \times 1.12 = 672000\). So, current profit is \(1080000 - 672000 = 408000\). The percentage change in profit is \(\frac{408000 - 400000}{400000} \times 100 = 2\%\) increase.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A bank offers a 5% annual interest rate on a savings account. If a customer deposits Rs. 10,000, how much interest will they earn in one year?
questions.explanation: The interest earned is calculated using the formula: Interest = Principal × Rate × Time. Here, Principal = Rs. 10,000, Rate = 5% = 0.05, Time = 1 year. Thus, Interest = 10,000 × 0.05 × 1 = Rs. 500.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A shopkeeper buys an article for Rs. 400 and sells it for Rs. 460. What is the profit percentage?
questions.explanation:
Profit = Selling Price (SP) - Cost Price (CP) = 460 - 400 = Rs. 60. 
Profit Percentage = (Profit/CP) × 100 = (60/400) × 100 = 15%.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A train 150 meters long is running at a speed of 54 km/h. In how much time will it cross a man running at 6 km/h in the opposite direction?
questions.explanation:
The relative speed of the train and the man is the sum of their speeds because they are moving in opposite directions:

Relative Speed = 54 km/h + 6 km/h = 60 km/h.

Converting this speed to meters per second:

60 km/h = (60 × 1000) / 3600 = 50/3 m/s.

The time taken to cross the man is the length of the train divided by the relative speed:

Time = Distance / Speed = 150 m / (50/3 m/s) = 150 × 3 / 50 = 9 seconds.

Therefore, the train will cross the man in 9 seconds.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A car travels 60 km at an average speed of 30 km/hr and the next 90 km at an average speed of 45 km/hr. What is the average speed of the car for the entire journey?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate total time for each segment. 
For 60 km at 30 km/hr, time = 60/30 = 2 hours. 
For 90 km at 45 km/hr, time = 90/45 = 2 hours.
Step 2: Total distance = 60 + 90 = 150 km, Total time = 2 + 2 = 4 hours.
Step 3: Average speed = Total Distance / Total Time = 150 km / 4 hours = 37.5 km/hr.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: The average salary of 5 employees in a company is INR 48,000. If a new employee joins the company and the average salary becomes INR 50,000, what is the salary of the new employee?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate the total salary of 5 employees: Total = 48,000 * 5 = INR 240,000. 
Step 2: Calculate the total salary of 6 employees: New Total = 50,000 * 6 = INR 300,000.
Step 3: Find the salary of the new employee: New Employee Salary = New Total - Old Total = 300,000 - 240,000 = INR 60,000.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: The average salary of 8 employees in a company is $45,000. If a new employee joins the company, the new average salary becomes $46,000. What is the salary of the new employee?
questions.explanation:
Let the salary of the new employee be $X.
The total salary of 8 employees = 8 * 45,000 = $360,000.
After the new employee joins, the total number of employees = 9.
The new average salary = $46,000, so the total salary = 9 * 46,000 = $414,000.
Thus, X + 360,000 = 414,000.
Solving for X, we get X = 414,000 - 360,000 = $54,000.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A sum of money is to be divided between P, Q, and R in the ratio of 3:4:5. If the total amount is ₹2400, how much more does R get than P?
questions.explanation: The sum of the parts of the ratio is 3 + 4 + 5 = 12. Each part is ₹2400 / 12 = ₹200. P gets 3 parts = 3 * ₹200 = ₹600. R gets 5 parts = 5 * ₹200 = ₹1000. R gets ₹1000 - ₹600 = ₹400 more than P.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: The average salary of 8 employees in a company is $45,000. The salary of one of the employees, who earns $55,000, is replaced by a new employee. If the new average salary becomes $44,000, what is the salary of the new employee?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate the total salary of the original 8 employees. Total = 45,000 * 8 = $360,000.
Step 2: The salary of one employee ($55,000) is replaced, so the new total salary = 44,000 * 8 = $352,000.
Step 3: The difference in total salary = $360,000 - $352,000 = $8,000.
Step 4: Therefore, the salary of the new employee = $55,000 - $8,000 = $47,000.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A train travels at an average speed of 60 km/h for 2 hours and then at an average speed of 90 km/h for 1 hour. What is the overall average speed of the train for the entire journey?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate the total distance traveled. Distance at 60 km/h = 60 * 2 = 120 km. Distance at 90 km/h = 90 * 1 = 90 km.
Step 2: Total distance = 120 + 90 = 210 km.
Step 3: Total time = 2 + 1 = 3 hours.
Step 4: Overall average speed = Total distance / Total time = 210 / 3 = 70 km/h.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A train 180 meters long is running at 54 km/hr. How much time will it take to cross a 240-meter-long bridge?
questions.explanation: Speed of train = 54 km/hr = 54 × 1000/3600 = 15 m/s. Total distance to cover = 180 + 240 = 420 meters. Time = Distance / Speed = 420 / 15 = 28 seconds.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: A container has a mixture of two liquids A and B in the ratio 7:5. When 9 liters of the mixture are drawn off and the container is filled with B, the ratio becomes 7:9. Find the initial quantity of liquid A in the container.
questions.explanation:
Let the initial quantities of A and B be 7x and 5x liters respectively.

After removing 9 liters of the mixture, the quantities become:

A = 7x - 9*(7/12) = 7x - 21/4
B = 5x - 9*(5/12) + 9 = 5x - 15/4 + 9

After adding the B, the new ratio is 7:9.

(7x - 21/4) / (5x - 15/4 + 9) = 7/9

Solving, we get:

9(7x - 21/4) = 7(5x - 15/4 + 9)

Simplifying yields x = 5.

Thus, initial quantity of A = 7x = 7*5 = 35 liters. The correct answer is C.
questions.subject: Arithmetic

questions.question: Workers A, B, and C are hired to complete a project. A can complete it in 10 days, B in 15 days, and C in 20 days. If they work together and are paid a total of $6000, what is A's share of the payment?
questions.explanation:
Total work = LCM(10, 15, 20) = 60 units
A's work rate = 60/10 = 6 units/day
B's work rate = 60/15 = 4 units/day
C's work rate = 60/20 = 3 units/day
Total work rate = 6 + 4 + 3 = 13 units/day
A's share = (A's work rate / Total work rate) * Total payment
